newsitem.title: USA: White House mulling oil/gas pipeline safety bill.
newsitem.headline: White House mulling oil/gas pipeline safety bill.

text.p: The Clinton administration is weighing whether to sign an oil and natural gas pipeline regulation bill that a several House Democrats blasted as a "pipeline deregulation bill."
The White House has not decided on the legislation, but is to act on it by October 14, an administration official said.

Democratic Reps. John Dingell of Michigan, Frank Pallone of New Jersey, Edward Markey of Massachusetts, Henry Waxman of California and George Miller of California in a letter urged President Clinton to veto the bill. "This bill, drafted with far more input from industry than from House Democrats, allows pipeline operators to decide for themselves which safety precautions to take and which to ignore, while making it more difficult for federal regulators to promulgate safety requirements," the congressmen said in a letter.
But the Transportation Department's Office of Pipeline Safety endorsed the bill, which the Senate passed unanimously and the House passed 276-125.
The bill requires regulators to make more use of cost-assessment studies and risk analyses in setting new rules.
